sentences.text:
Basically, when I insert a removable device (either USB drive or CD or 
DVD ...)
, the disque is correctly detected and even mounted.

However, 
Gnome does not see that and if I try to access the disc from the Gnome 
file manager, it will try to remount it and, of course, fail.

This is an important bug as it renders the use of a DVD with totem 
impossible.

As stated in the bug report #309350, restarting the dbus service allows 
gnome to recognise the device, but it will *never* be unmounted (for 
gnome) after that, even if restarting dbus.
Versions of packages gnome-volume-manager depends on:

ii  gconf2                 2.12.1-9          GNOME configuration database syste
ii  hal                    0.5.6-4           Hardware Abstraction Layer

On Wed, Feb 22, 2006 at 03:41:51PM +0100, Pierre Barbier de Reuille wrote:

> Basically, when I insert a removable device (either USB drive or CD or 
> DVD ...)
, the disque is correctly detected and even mounted.

However, 
> Gnome does not see that and if I try to access the disc from the Gnome 
> file manager, it will try to remount it and, of course, fail.

> This is an important bug as it renders the use of a DVD with totem 
> impossible.

> As stated in the bug report #309350, restarting the dbus service allows 
> gnome to recognise the device, but it will *never* be unmounted (for 
> gnome) after that, even if restarting dbus.
Sorry for the late reply, had some busy weeks.

This is either a hal or a 
gnome-vfs2 issue.

Could you mail the output of lshal --monitor when you mount 
and/or unmount a DVD ?

And ofcourse please try with the latest version of hal
and gnome-vfs2
Fain would I climb, yet fear I to fall.

Since this bug is also bugging me, I thought I'd go ahead and share my
own ouput to lshal --monitor.

This is what it gave me when I plugged in
a standard 512 MB USB flash drive:
After this, /media/EspeonEefi (EspeonEefi is the label of the drive)
existed, and it contained the contents of the flash drive.

No icon
showed up on the Desktop, though.

The Computer folder in Nautilus also
contained an icon for a USB drive, but double-clicking on it gave me the
error that the drive was already mounted.

pumount /media/EspeonEefi seemed to unmount the drive and delete
/media/EspeonEefi just fine.

On Sat, Mar 18, 2006 at 04:07:49PM -0500, EspeonEefi wrote:

> Since this bug is also bugging me, I thought I'd go ahead and share my
> own ouput to lshal --monitor.

This is what it gave me when I plugged in
> a standard 512 MB USB flash drive:
Please update your kernel to >= 2.6.15, that should fix the problem..
The truth is rarely pure, and never simple.

I was about to complain that my use of fglrx was keeping me from
upgrading (the version in unstable was not compatible with 2.6.15 or
X.org 6.9), but what do I find during today's aptitude update but
updated fglrx packages that work with all the new toys!

A kernel upgrade
later, things indeed are working well for me.

"Protozoa are small, and bacteria are small, but viruses are smaller
than the both put together."

title: gnome-volume-manager: Removable devices mounted but not shown
